ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

HOUGANG NEW TOWN
(School Building Programme)


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education what plans there are to build primary and secondary schools and junior colleges in Hougang New Town.

     The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Education (Mr Ho Kah Leong) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, under the current School Building Programme, eight schools will be built in Hougang New Town, consisting of five primary schools and three secondary schools.

    A site has been reserved for a junior college under the Ministry's proposed third junior college building programme which will be reviewed in 1985.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Sir, may I ask the Parliamentary Secretary how many of these schools will be built in the Punggol constituency?

     Mr Ho Kah Leong: Sir, I am pleased to inform the hon. Member that, out of the eight new schools, three primary schools and one secondary school will be built in the Punggol constituency. The rest will be in the Paya Lebar constituency.

Column: 923

AIDED-SCHOOLS
(Applications for capital grants)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education if he will state the number of applications for capital grants following the announcement in 1982 that aided schools can obtain a grant of up to 80% of project cost; whether aided schools will be allowed to use Government schools that are now being built to avoid the submission of building plans for approval and the application to solicit funds to build new schools or expand their existing substandard schools to provide better facilities; and whether his Ministry can be more flexible in regard to the payment of 20% of

Column: 924

the building cost required to be raised by the aided schools, in view of their contributions to Singapore.

     The Minister of State of Education (Dr Tay Eng Soon) (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, since the announcement to provide up to 80% of project cost to aided-schools last May, 15 applications have been received. Eleven are for relocation of schools and four are for major extension projects.

    Aided-schools may occupy new schools built by Government at nominal rent for three years in the first instance, whilst they raise funds to pay their share of the cost of the property. Five aided-schools have moved into new Government schools under this scheme.

    The Ministry of Education will be flexible. It will consider extension of the rental period in the event that an aided-school is not able to raise sufficient funds within the stipulated period.

     Mr Ng Kah Ting: Sir, can the Minister of State enlighten this House which are the five aided-schools that he has mentioned have moved into new Government schools?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, the five aided-schools are: St Thomas Secondary School, Fairfield Methodist Secondary School, Fairfield Methodist Primary School, Nan Hwa Girls' High School and Presbyterian High School.

Column: 924

PREMATURE SCHOOL LEAVERS


    3. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education what are the number and percentage of premature school-leavers for each level from Primary 1 to Secondary 4 in 1982, and whether streaming has reduced the number of premature school-leavers in that year.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, in 1982, the total number of pupils who left primary school pre-maturely was 2,755. This amounted to 0.94% of the total primary school enrolment which was 291,686. The majority of

Column: 925

these pupils (about 66%) were from Primary 6, Primary 7 Extended Course and the Basic 4 Course.

    For comparison, in 1978, the year before primary school streaming was introduced, the total number of premature primary school leavers was 8,900 or 3% of the total enrolment of 296,922. The introduction of streaming has, therefore, reduced the number of premature primary school leavers by more than three-fold.

    In 1982, secondary streaming had reached only Secondary 2 level. The total number of premature school leavers from Secondary 1 and 2 were 1,605 or 1.9% of the total enrolment for the two levels. In contrast, for the same two levels in 1978, the total number of premature school leavers were 8,007 or 9.3% of the total enrolment. The reduction in dropout rate between the two years is nearly five-fold.

    In absolute terms, the difference between 1978 and 1982 was a saving of over 12,500 pupils from becoming drop-outs.

Column: 925

SPECIAL ASSISTANCE PLAN SCHOOLS


    4. Mr Liew Kok Pun asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education what is the future development of the Special Assistance Plan (SAP) schools.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, the future of the Special course will depend on the ability of the SAP schools to attract enough students from the top 10% to do the course. Up to now, these students have come from both the Chinese and English primary streams. In 1979, when the SAP school programme was started, the total enrolment consisted of 65% from the CL (Chinese language) stream and 35% from the EL (English language) stream. This year, the ratio was 40% from the CL stream and 60% from the EL stream. The overall intake had also fallen from 1,455 in 1979, representing 48.5% of those from the top 10%, to 1,255 or 38.8% for 1983.

Column: 926



    The intake from the CL stream will fall drastically in the future as enrolment in the primary CL stream continues to decline. his year, only 2% of the Primary 1 intake as for the CL stream. The overall intake into the SAP schools is, therefore, likely to decline unless more able pupils from the EL stream can be induced to join the SAP schools.

    It would be Singapore's loss if some of our best Chinese secondary schools should decline to become mediocre schools because good students are going to the EL schools instead of the SAP schools. Apart from their high academic standards, these schools possess an ethos which has over the years produced students with a strong sense of discipline and seriousness of purpose. This quality of the best Chinese schools is linked to the quality of their principals and teaching staff. For these schools to survive, they must continue to attract able students not only to the Special course but also to their Express course.

    The results of the first batch of Special course students to take their 'O' level are very good. They demonstrate that it is possible for very able students to take EL1 and CL1 and do as well as those among the same top 10% in the non-SAP stream.

    However, recognizing that the intake into the SAP schools is likely to decline because of the large decrease in CL stream primary enrolment, the Ministry is proposing to allow students from the top 10% at PSLE to join the Express course in the SAP schools to do EL1 and CL2. This will attract some of the better pupils from the EL primary schools to join the SAP schools, since they will not be deterred by having to do EL1 and CL1. Of course, those who want to opt to do the Special course, i.e. EL1 and CL1, can continue to do so. This measure will enlarge the intake of able students into the SAP schools.

    The ability of the SAP schools to maintain the Special course will depend on the demand for the course. If the intake continues to decline in some of the SAP schools, it may be necessary to transfer their Special course to the more viable SAP schools: These schools will then revert to regular schools offering Express and Normal courses.

Column: 927



     Encik Mansor Haji Sukaimi (Kampong Kembangan): Sir, what are the reasons for the preference of parents to send their children to the EL schools and not to the SAP schools?

     Dr Tay Eng Soon: Sir, it is well known that for many years now since the 1950s parents in Singapore have been sending their children, in increasing numbers, to the English stream. In the 1970s the number of pupils sent by parents to the Chinese stream continued to fall. What we have observed of parents wanting to send their children to the non-SAP schools instead of the SAP stream is part of the same trend. The reason is simply an economic and a rational one because most parents recognize the importance of English as the working language in Singapore by virtue of our peculiar position in the world economy.

Column: 927

COMPUTER APPRECIATION CLUBS
(Training of Teachers)


    5. Mr Lim Boon Heng asked the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education how many teachers have been trained to supervise computer appreciation clubs in secondary schools; how many students are members of such clubs; how much computer time is available to each student member per week; and whether his Ministry plans to provide schools with more micro-computers.

     Dr Tay Eng Soon (for the First Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Education): Sir, to date, 438 teachers have been trained to supervise Computer Appreciation Clubs in secondary schools. Another 137 teachers are currently under-going training. They will complete their training in May 1983. A further group of 80 teachers is targetted to undergo training in July 1983. By the end of 1983, it is estimated that 655 teachers would have been trained.

    About 8,000 students are members of these Computer Appreciation Clubs. It is expected that the total membership of the clubs will increase to 13,000 by the end of 1983.

Column: 928



    The average computer time available for each student member is about half an hour a week.

    334 micro-computers have been distributed to 131 secondary schools. 82 schools have been provided with three micro-computer systems each. The rest have between one and two systems each. The Ministry is looking into the possibility of providing more micro-computers for schools.

Column: 928

MR PHEY YEW KOK
(Efforts to locate)


    6. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for Home Affairs whether any further progress has been made by the Police to locate the former President of the National Trades Union Congress and People's Action Party Member of Parliament Mr Phey Yew Kok and what steps, if any, have been taken since his last reply in this House.

     The Minister for Home Affairs (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, he was last known to be in a nearby country without extradition arrangements with Singapore. There has been no further development. There is an alert for the apprehension of the fugitive issued by Interpol HQ. It will remain in force until he is apprehended.

    His options are to fester in exile, away from his family and friends in Singapore, or face the charges against him.

     Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam (Anson): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Hon. Minister states that he was last known to be in a neighbouring country with which we have no extradition treaty or arrangements. What is the date of this last known knowledge of the Police, and would he inform us of this country with which we have no arrangements? The other question is this. I understand the family is here. Are the Police aware whether the family is in touch with this man or not?

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, I do not think it is prudent on my part to reveal in public the name of the nearby country in which he was last heard of. However, if the Member for Anson is curious about it, he can write to me and I shall give him the information in strict confidence, just to

Column: 929

satisfy his curiosity. It is not prudent for me to mention it in public, because it may hamper the efforts of Interpol and the Police to apprehend him. As far as the date is concerned, it was quite some time ago. I do not think I should also reveal the time when he was last heard of.

    With regard to the second question, i.e. whether the Police have got information as to whether he has been in touch with his family, the answer is no. We have no such information. If we have, we would have followed it up.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not asking questions out of idle curiosity. I think these questions are of public interest. Honestly, I cannot understand what objections there can be to the Minister informing this House of the country where he was last known to have been and the date. Secondly, I would like to know why the Police, with all the competence that they are known to possess in Singapore, have been unable to find out from the family whether they are in correspondence with the man or not.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask the Member for Anson: is there any objection in my giving that information to him in confidence? Does he object to that?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I said this is a matter of public interest. This House is entitled to know. It is not me who should be told this in confidence, that I can keep it to myself. It is a question of public interest. This House should know and the public in Singapore should know.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: But in my opinion I do not think it is in the public interest to make it known. To satisfy his curiosity or any imputation of smear he is making, I am prepared to give it to him in strict confidence.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: I do not want it in strict confidence.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: To what purpose?

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the public are entitled to know what efforts

Column: 930

are being made to bring this man back to Singapore. I think that will be evident.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, that is quite different from what efforts have been made to bring him back to Singapore. In fact, I have answered the question on the efforts that have been made to bring him to book. We have contacted the Interpol Police and they have put out an alert. If they find him, he will be apprehended. What are the other things necessary to make public?

    As far as the other question is concerned, he has twisted it again. At first he asked: is there any information which the Police has come into its possession as to whether he has been in contact with his family? The answer is no. If we have such information, we would have followed it up. That is quite different from his second allegation that no effort has been made on the part of the Police to find out from his family whether he has been in contact with members of his family. If the Member had put it that way, i.e. has any effort been made to find out from his family whether they have been in contact, the answer is yes. We do try now and again to find out, but the answer, as far as the family is concerned, is that he has not been in contact.

    However, if the Member for Anson has any information whether he has been in contact with his family or he has contacted any lawyer or himself in a professional capacity, if he would tell me in strict confidence I will keep that confidence and act upon it.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the Minister may rest assured that I shall not only inform him but I shall also make it known if I know where the man is. I shall make it known to the public.

    With due respect, all we have heard is a lot of euphemism from the Minister. Would the Minister state categorically what are the objections to it being made public in this House? He talks about hampering the efforts of Interpol. How will it hamper? I would like to know for one.

     Mr Chua Sian Chin: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is pretty obvious. If you are trying to apprehend a person and if you have

Column: 931

information of his whereabouts, you do not reveal it in public. Otherwise he will make arrangements to avoid apprehension.

Column: 931

PUNGGOL RURAL CENTRE
(Development of adjacent vacant land)


    7. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development whether he is aware that the residents of Punggol Rural Centre are without shopping and marketing facilities, and, since the adjacent land is vacant, if he will consider building there several blocks of housing units to include shops and a market and, if so, when they will be completed.

     The Minister of State for National Development (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board will develop the vacant land adjacent to the existing Punggol Rural Centre to provide 222 dwelling units, 12 shops with quarters and two eating houses. The project is scheduled to commence in the last quarter of 1984 and is expected to be completed by mid-1986. The HDB will not build a market to serve the Centre as there will be only 550 dwelling units, comprising 328 existing flats and 222 proposed units. To be viable, a standard HDB market requires a catchment of between 4,000 and 6,000 dwelling units. However, some of the shop units in the proposed development will be set aside as meat, fish and market produce shops to serve residents of the Centre.

Column: 931

YISHUN NEW TOWN
(Building of 4- and 5-room flats)


    8. Dr Koh Lip Lin asked the Minister for National Development (a) why there are so few 4-room and 5-room flats among the flats which have been built in Yishun New Town; (b) how many units of 4-room and 5-room flats will be built there in 1983 and 1984; and (c) when will the first market/ food centre in the New Town be ready.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB has completed 440 4-room and 52 5-room flats in Yishun New Town. Construction of these flats commenced at

Column: 932

the end of 1980 when applications for 4-and 5-room units totalled 235 and 40 respectively. At that time, the number of flats built was sufficient to meet the rather low demand for 4- and 5-room units in Yishun. The HDB could not afford to award more contracts in anticipation of future demand as its resources were channelled to meet the greater demand in other zones.

    The HDB will build 763 4-room flats in Yishun in 1983. It will build 5,290 4-room flats and 568 5-room flats in 1984.

    The first market and food centre in Yishun will be completed by August 1984.

     Dr Koh Lip Lin (Nee Soon): Sir, is the new market going to be a conventional one, or is it going to be the new air-conditioned type of market?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB has stopped building any more wet markets for a variety of reasons. The new market will be the new type with market produce stalls and so forth.

Column: 932

SELETAR EXPRESSWAY
(Construction of link between Yio Chu Kang Road and Mandai Road)


    9. Dr Koh Lip Lin asked the Minister for National Development when construction work on the proposed Seletar Expressway linking Yio Chu Kang Road and Mandai Road will begin and when will it be completed.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the proposed Seletar Expressway is part of the island-wide expressway network to be built by the Public Works Department in the next 10 years. It is a northward extension of the Central Expressway. It will stretch from Yio Chu Kang Road in the south to the Bukit Timah Expressway near Woodlands New Town in the north.

    The construction of the Seletar Expressway will only commence after the completion of the northern stretch of the Central Expressway from Jalan Toa Payoh to Yio Chu Kang (formerly called the Sembawang Expressway). Part of the Central Expressway between Jalan Toa Payoh and Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 is nearing

Column: 933

completion and will be opened to traffic by the end of this month. Construction of the other part from Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1 to Yio Chu Kang Road will commence in late 1984 and will be completed by late 1987. The implementation of the Seletar Expressway project can therefore be expected to be undertaken in the late 1980s. However, as detailed design for this new expressway has yet to commence, it is too early to determine its exact implementation schedule.

Column: 933

HDB COMMERCIAL/INDUSTRIAL PREMISES
(Transfer fee)


    10. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development if he will state the reason for the levy of $500.00 by the Housing and Development Board for the transfer of tenancy of its commercial/industrial premises from the tenant to a partner or next of kin.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan (for the Minister for National Development): Mr Speaker, Sir, the HDB charges a transfer fee of $500 when the registered tenant of a commercial or industrial premises transfers his tenancy to a business partner or a next of kin who has been assisting him in his business.

    The fee, in fact, is a token charge. Transfers of tenancy are generally not allowed as they enable new tenants to enjoy the subsidized rentals of original tenants which are far below rentals that can be fetched by tender on the open market. Transfers of tenancy also allow a new tenant to enjoy the reputation and goodwill of the original tenant.

    The HDB has considered charging prevailing market rentals for transfer tenancies but decided against this as it would cause undue hardship to a partner or next of kin of the original tenant.

    The transfer fee is therefore a concession given by the HDB. It is not imposed when the transfer of a tenancy to a next of kin is necessitated by the death of the registered tenant.

Column: 934



     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, in the written reply that was given, the answer was that this was to defray administrative costs. If that is correct, that it was to defray administrative costs and not a levy or a fine that the man has to pay for transferring the tenancy, I want to know what are the administrative costs involved. That was the answer that was given when I asked that question - it was to defray administrative costs. What are these costs?

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: The Member for Anson is referring to a written reply which we gave to him when he wanted to know a whole long list of fees and charges imposed by the HDB. Therefore, in the summary table it was only possible for us to give the various reasons in point form. One of the reasons for this fee is obviously for the administrative effort involved. But the reason is, as I have given just now in more detail, that it is basically a token charge. The normal policy is that we do not allow a transfer of tenancy. But we have made a concession in these cases to allow it, and in so doing we charge a token fee.

     Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State whether he is aware or whether he has any idea how much transfer fee is involved for a transfer of tenancy of a private property.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, I think the question should best be directed to the Member for Anson who is a lawyer. But, as is well known, the fees could be very substantial in terms of stamp fees and so on. Very often there is consideration involved because you are transferring something of value from one person to another. In this case our policy is that this tenancy really belongs to the HDB. It is not a property to be transferred from one tenant to another. We have actually made a concession in this case, by allowing a transfer in special cases and with a token charge.

     Mr Jeyaretnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, with respect, I really cannot follow the Hon. Minister of State. As I understand the written answer to my question, a fee is charged when the transfer is from one partner to another partner. Now the

Column: 935

Minister of State talks about a new tenant coming in. If a coffee shop is run by a firm, there are several partners. It is the firm that is continuing. And if it is considered expedient or, for some reason, necessary that the tenancy should be held by A instead of B in the same firm, what is the reason for levying a $500 charge? The Minister of State talks about it being a token. I do not know whether it is being regarded as a token.

     Mr Lee Yock Suan: Mr Speaker, Sir, this is not the first time that the Member for Anson has not been able to follow logical argument. I think the Members are hardly surprised and, in fact, I despair at having to explain to him. But the fact is that if the original tenancy was given to this partnership, the partners Mr A and Mr B, in the proportion of maybe 50-50, then when A transfers or gives up his share to B, B gets a 100% share. So there is a change in the original conditions. B is now getting a bigger share, and often this means that he is enjoying a bigger rental subsidy, and so on. Normally we would not allow a transfer. If, for example, A wants to transfer his share to someone completely new, we will say, "No. You bring this back to us. You tender again." This is because the market rental is different, and these are month-to-month tenancies. If A wants to take in a new partner, we will allow it, but then we will revise the rent to the market rental. So the Member must understand the basic premise. I can see a lot of confusion on his face, but as I have said, it is hardly surprising.

BEST PROGRAMME FOR NATIONAL SERVICEMEN


    11. Dr Koh Lip Lin asked the Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health why the Ministry of Defence is introducing the BEST Programme for some National Servicemen, in view of the relatively short period of 2 to 2 1/2 years available to the Singapore Armed Forces to convert them into well-trained combat-ready soldiers.

     The Minister of State of Defence (Dr Yeo Ning Hong) (for the Minister of Defence and Second Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, the BEST Programme is part of the national effort to raise the basic educational level of our workforce.

Column: 936

Annually, about 4,500 National Servicemen who can benefit from such basic education are enlisted into the SAF. Two years later, they will leave the SAF to join the national workforce. They will remain in the workforce for the next 30 or more years. The productivity and future well-being of these workers are at stake if they are not given extra assistance to improve their basic educational skills right away.

    It is MINDEF's contribution to our servicemen to see that they leave the SAF after two years of full-time national service not only as well trained proficient soldiers but that they are also better prepared for their civilian career. The BEST Programme in the SAF will help them. By helping them in their basic education in literacy skills, it is also an expression of MINDEF's concern for the soldier's welfare.

    The national BEST Programme consists of two subjects: English and Mathematics. There are four modules per subject. Each module requires approximately 60 hours of instruction. MINDEF has carried out a feasibility study and this indicates that two modules of each subject can be implemented within a two-year NS period. This is bearing in mind that military training and operational readiness must be our primary priorities. We have decided to have classes for English because English is of much more immediate value both to the soldiers while they are in the SAF as well as to them as Reservists after they leave the SAF. Two modules of English Language instruction will take up approximately 120 hours of instruction time and this will be spread over the entire two years of national service.

WALK-WAYS AND PEDESTRIAN-MALLS


    3. Mr J.B. Jeyaretnam asked the Minister for National Development if he will give the total amount spent on the construction, reconditioning, renovation and renewal of walk-ways and pedestrian-malls in 1982.

     Mr Teh Cheang Wan: In 1982, a total of $502,002 was spent on the construction of new pedestrian walkways and footpaths. Another $2,309,539 was spent on the repairs and maintenance of existing footpaths and kerbs.
